Name: Rwanda Bufcafe
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a bright, pure but complex morning cup.

Name: Rwanda Fair Trade Cafe Feminino
Review: ong>Pure and meadowy but richly authoritative. Sweetness and flowers without sentimentality.

Name: Kenya Mamuto
Review: ong>Brightly acidy but sweetly inviting, vibrantly complex Kenya.

Name: Panama Lerida Estate
Review: ong>Superb balance of lush sweetness, crisply dry mouthfeel and dynamically complex aromatics should please both coffee classicist and romantic.

Name: Elizer Espresso
Review: ong>It’s hard to imagine a much better candidate for a classic cappuccino or espresso macchiato, but makes a smoothly authoritative straight shot as well.

Name: El Roble Colombia Santander
Review: ong>Balanced, delicate, comfortable, though with gentle aromatic surprises.

Name: Tano Batak Sumatra
Review: ong>The beloved Sumatra earth and fruit character at its purest and most intense.

Name: Kona Peaberry Medium Roast
Review: ong>A very fine Kona in the classic pure, sweet-toned style, a style that is increasingly hard to find in Kona owing to careless fruit removal and drying and tactless dark roasting.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa (North Kona District), Big Island of Hawaii.

Name: San Augustin Guatemala Antigua
Review: ong>Balanced, naturally sweet, quietly but lushly complex.

Name: Easter Sunrise Blend
Review: ong>Lovers of the idiosyncratic. Those who enjoy Islay single-malt whiskies, lapsang souchong teas, heavy beverages that shock and surprise.

Name: Ethiopian Shanta Golba Espresso Fair Trade
Review: ong>Particularly distinctive and agreeable in short milk with its stone fruit and chocolate notes, while the straight shot will please those who enjoy rough but engaging fruit-toned beverages.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya AA Ruiru Mills Estate
Review: ong>Unusual Kenya profile, deep and savory sweet with layered complexity. Suggests pairing with desserts.

Name: SO Espresso Brazil Corrego Seco Dark Roast
Review: ong>Those who like gently suave blends like Illy Caffé but crave just a bit more bite and complexity. A single-origin espresso with impressive balance and completeness.
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil.

Name: Laura’s Blend: 100 Percent Kona Coffee Fancy
Review: ong>Simply a perfect expression of the sweet, balanced, quietly complete Kona cup.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, Hawaii.

Name: Ethiopian Tchembe Amaro Gayo
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the rich, brandied chocolate fruit of a fine dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia coffee. Not a purist’s coffee, but a rather pure example of this exotic type.

Name: Venice Nights
Review: ong>Delicate but genuinely exotic profile. Blends of dramatically darker and lighter roasted coffees are hard to pull off; this one succeeds.

Name: ChacolaTAY Blend
Review: ong>Lovely, balanced blend fresh with earth, fruit and honeyish floral notes.

Name: Kenya Gichatha-Ini
Review: ong>Lovers of those aperitif and dessert wines that combine fruit notes with herb and aromatic wood.

Name: El Salvador Finca El Majahual
Review: ong>Lovers of good port wines.

Name: Kenya Kangocho
Review: ong>Those who enjoy foods and beverages with unorthodox juxtapositions of taste and flavor: salted plums, for example, stewed fruits, certain mescals and grappas.

Name: Burundi Kiryama Micro Lot 8
Review: ong>The sort of crisp yet luxurious coffee that used to be tagged for “after dinner,” but I’d say drink it anytime.

Name: Ethiopian Sidamo Shanta Golba Natural Processed
Review: ong>Those who favor fruit-forward red wines with lots of oak may be particularly well-suited candidates for this engaging, rather muscular and complex version of the Ethiopia dried-in-the-fruit cup, one that comes with reassuring environmental and social credentials.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Brasil Fazenda Sertao
Review: ong>Balanced, delicate breakfast cup with light body but refined finish.
Coffee Origin: Carmo de Minas growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil

Name: Brazil Zinho Peaberry Natural
Review: ong>Those who prefer a mild roasty pungency in a chocolate-and-walnut-toned Brazil.
Coffee Origin: Campos Altos growing district, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Organic Brazil Diamantina
Review: ong>A lightish roast and clean wet processing encourages a fresh, molasses-like sweetness and gently lively acidity.
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil.

Name: Brazilian, Medium Roast
Review: ong>Crisp, subtle, silky. An attractive alternative for those who avoid intense, acidy coffees for reasons of health or taste.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Floresta
Review: ong>Those looking for a juicy, honey-toned morning cup.
Roaster Location: Salt Spring Island, British Colombia, Canada
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Monte Alegre
Review: ong>A classic Brazil, syrupy, balanced, chocolaty.
Coffee Origin: Sul de Minas growing region, southern Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Sitio do Tanque
Review: ong>Those who prefer subtle but opulent beverages.
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil.

Name: Brazil Fazenda Chapadao de Ferro Peaberry
Review: ong>Acidity is functional but gentle and backgrounded while dark chocolate and nut notes dominate, making this a complex but comfortable coffee for those who find coffees from East Africa or Central America too forceful or bright.
Coffee Origin: Patrocinio region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Sol do Paraguassu Farm Natural Processed Brazil
Review: ong>Balanced, gentle, refreshing Brazil, quietly exceptional.
Coffee Origin: Chapada Diamantina growing region, Bahia State, Brazil.

Name: El Vergel Guatemala
Review: ong>Extraordinary coffee, superlative in all the classic ways.

Name: Colombia Finca Villa Loyola
Review: ong>Complete coffee in the classic Colombia mode.

Name: Colombian La Esperanza
Review: ong>Big, complete and balanced, a classic Colombia.
Coffee Origin: Valle del Cauca growing region, Colombia.

Name: Tano Batak Sumatra
Review: ong>Elegantly complex, refined version of the earth and pungent fruit sensations beloved of generations of Sumatra drinkers.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing region, North Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Gacokwe Burundi
Review: ong>Quietly exotic variation on the Bourbon-influenced Burundi cup: pungently sweet, aromatic wood saturated in vanilla and flowers.

Name: Bolivia Marcial Huanca
Review: ong>Big but balanced, sweetly complex classic Latin-American breakfast cup.

Name: Guatemalan La Joya
Review: ong>A fine, balanced, gently crisp cup of the style associated with the best Guatemalas.

Name: House Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A very nicely balanced blend for K-cuppers, rounded and deepened by a tactful medium-dark roast.

Name: Sumatra Reserve Extra Bold Fair Trade Organic (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A gentle version of the pungent, cedary chocolate Sumatra profile with bonus social and environmental credentials for K-cup drinkers. Those whose brewers offer the option of brewing at four ounces will find the Sumatra character more pronounced at the smaller, more concentrated serving size.

Name: P&F Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who prefer a deep, resonantly complex straight shot.

Name: Rwanda Gatare Cup of Excellence Lot 6
Review: ong>Those who enjoy dry, floral-toned white wines and the pungent dry-berry elegance of fine Kenya coffees.

Name: Sumatra Red Badger
Review: ong>Non-gardening Sumatra drinkers. A still pungent but rather bright version of the classic Sumatra profile, with only a discreet hint of the usual musty earth.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AA Gaturiri
Review: ong>Those who enjoy big, dry white table wines with complex aromatics. This is an aficionado’s Kenya, elegant but uncompromising in its intense acidity and crisp, pungent fruit.

Name: Kenya AA Nyeri Gaturiri
Review: ong>An aficionado’s Kenya: complexly assertive acidity; rich, dry aromatics and flavor.

Name: El Salvador Finca Suiza Santa Ana
Review: ong>A syrupy body and tart yet ripe fruit notes should please those who indulge in ports and other dessert wines.
Coffee Origin: Santa Ana growing region, El Salvador.

Name: Colombia Pablo Zuniga Micro Lot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy tart, savory sensations like Meyer lemon or tomato-based juices.

Name: Colombia Fondo Paez Cooperative Organic
Review: ong>Those who think they may enjoy the distinctively dry, slightly savory cocoa, lemony sensation that dominates in this Colombia.

Name: Colombia Tolima Finca Las Florestales
Review: ong>Drinkers of heavily hopped floral ales and dry, aromatic white wines.

Name: Colombia Las Mercedes 2011 Cup of Excellence #2 Auction Lot
Review: ong>Lovers of very dry, light-bodied beverages: gins, minerally white table wines.

Name: Colombia San Agustin
Review: ong>Lovers of big, resonantly rich Colombias in the classic style.

Name: Colombia La Coqueta
Review: ong>Both strong-structured and aromatically subtle, with juicy hints of East Africa.

Name: Colombia Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a balanced but assertively bright breakfast cup.

Name: Colombia Piendamo Meseta de Popayan
Review: ong>Classically balanced, delicately complex morning cup. Take it black.

Name: Colombia Martha Cecelia Rojas
Review: ong>Those who take their coffee black and enjoy a delicate, naturally sweet-toned, cleanly aromatic cup.
Coffee Origin: Pitalito growing region, Huila Department, Colombia.

Name: Colombia Huila Monserrate Yaneth Gil Microlot
Review: ong>Breakfast classicists. This is a complete Colombia coffee, the kind I recall we used to get more often, balanced and flawless in virtually every respect.

Name: Sumatra Lintong Fully Washed
Review: ong>Smoothly bright, pungently refreshing example of the finest traditional style of Sumatra coffee.
Coffee Origin: Lintong growing district, northern Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Ethiopia Deep Blue Harrar
Review: ong>Rich, roundly fruit-toned cup should particularly please those who enjoy fine traditional dessert wines.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Interesting and transformative espresso that dominates but doesn’t overwhelm milk in small, cappuccino-sized beverages.

Name: BC Espresso
Review: ong>Delicate, lively straight shot that retains presence nicely in a variety of milk-based beverages.

Name: Espresso de Tropico
Review: ong>Those who favor full-bodied, syrupy porter-style ales in particular should enjoy the straight shot.

Name: Espresso Classico
Review: ong>No roasty or acidy sharpness but plenty of weight, complexity and presence make this a versatile espresso that masters milk nicely.

Name: Flores Bajawa Ngura Organic
Review: ong>Lovers of Sumatras and other earthy/fruity coffees. This is a romance coffee: exotic, challenging, exhilarating in its richly stated imperfections.

Name: Colombia El Roble Single Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Elegant single-origin espresso as impressive in short milk as it is as a straight shot.

Name: Opus One Espresso
Review: ong>Authoritative as straight shot and gently complex in short milk drinks.

Name: Bolivia “Taipiplaya” Fair Trade Organic Certified
Review: ong>Lovers of a sweetly crisp, quietly aromatic morning cup.

Name: Rwanda Dukunde Kawa Cooperative
Review: ong>Fine variation on the floral and citrus East Africa profile: crisp and refreshing morning cup.

Name: Rwanda
Review: ong>The versatility of this quietly complex moderate dark roast should please both black and with whitener.

Name: Concerto Psychedelico “Duo” Espresso
Review: ong>Perhaps at its best as a fragrantly smooth, pungently juicy straight shot, but pleasing in short milk as well.

Name: Kenya AA Top Single Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Impressive complexity and completeness in a single-origin espresso, both as straight shot and in milk.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Koke Organic
Review: ong>Delicate yet deeply resonant version of the great classic Yirgacheffe cup.

Name: Kenya AA Extra Bold (K-Cup)
Review: ong>K-Cup drinkers curious to experience the tart berry note so treasured in classic Kenyas. This note, and the general aromatic virtues of a suavely bright Kenya, are present here, if a bit subdued.

Name: Sumatra Reserve Fair-Trade Organic
Review: ong>A Fair Trade and organic presentation of the classic darker roasted Sumatra cup, gently earthy, roasty and chocolate-toned.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Gedeo Worka Fair Trade Organic Certified
Review: ong>Big-gestured, dramatic Yirgacheffe for lovers of this complexly aromatic origin.

Name: Kenya Meru Kinjo Peaberry
Review: ong>A powerfully acidy yet sweetly elegant version of the classic Kenya profile.

Name: El Salvador Santa Rita
Review: ong>Aficionados should admire the striking originality of this natural-processed profile with its complex anthology of savory-sweet fruit sensation.
Coffee Origin: Santa Rita growing region, El Salvador.

Name: Brothers Espresso
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a dry, zesty, aromatically complex small cup.

Name: Mexico Chiapas El Triunfo Biosphere Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Natural sweetness and an exquisitely delicate acidity make this coffee particularly appealing black; even habitual milk pourers should keep their hands off the white stuff with this graceful, crisp cup. Drink it hot; flavor tends to tail off as it cools.

Name: Guatemala Huehuetenango Fair Trade Certified
Review: ong>The acidity here is not an intense, brightly lemony sensation, but rather ripe, juicy, and complicated by a cedary, slightly earthy character. Lovers of minerally, complex, only moderately dry white table wines might be particular candidates for this coffee.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling Fair Trade Certified
Review: ong>A graceful version of the often rough and earthy Sumatra profile. The elements are all here: the moist earthy notes, aromatic wood, malty dark chocolate, butterscotch-like pungency, but in impressive, understated balance.

Name: Black Bar Espresso
Review: ong>A versatile espresso that shines on its own and can compliment even larger sized milk drinks.

Name: Original Blend
Review: ong>A potentially delicate, balanced breakfast cup that suffered in our sample from some aromatic fading. For supermarket shoppers a plausible all-Arabica alternative to the dismal, Robusta-based canned options.

Name: Veranda Blend
Review: ong>Medium-roast drinkers who find themselves out of coffee and close to a Starbucks.

Name: Cafe Domingo
Review: ong>Those who find directness and simplicity a virtue.

Name: Willow Blend
Review: ong>This perhaps half-hearted rendition of a traditional medium roast may be aimed at Dunkin’ Donuts drinkers. It seems far too muted for those who enjoy the more assertive acidity and complex aromatics of coffees from the newer, trendier medium-roasters.

Name: House Blend
Review: ong>A forceful, deep-structured cup, especially when hot.

Name: Holler Mountain Organic
Review: ong>Those who prefer a robust, muscular richness to balance.

Name: Cafe Solano
Review: ong>A versatile cup with quiet, balanced authority.

Name: Farm House Organic
Review: ong>Lovers of fresh, aromatically arresting breakfast coffees.

Name: Kenya Gethumbwini
Review: ong>Those who enjoy fine white table wines that balance mineral and fruit. An impressive Kenya in the slightly austere, elegant dry berry style.

Name: Ethiopia Tuktant Natural Process
Review: ong>An unusual brisk natural Ethiopia. Aficionados interested in variants on the great Ethiopia cup may particular enjoy it.

Name: Bali Kintamani Organic Natural Process
Review: ong>The explosive aromatics combined with the sweet-salt-savory structure may appeal to lovers of tequilas and some single malt whiskies.

Name: Burundi Kayanza
Review: ong>Energetic and arresting cup. The unusual savory sweet complexity may reflect the heirloom Bourbon cultivar, which is widely grown in Burundi.

Name: Colombian Fair Trade Select
Review: ong>Coffee romantics. Exotic aroma and flavor notes make this coffee more African than Colombian.

Name: Nantucket Blend (K-Cup)
Review: ong>A delicate, gently balanced morning cup for K-Cuppers.

Name: Gourmet Blend Regular
Review: ong>Low acidity, but given this sample’s badly tainted green coffees, not recommended even for acidity-avoiders.

Name: House Blend
Review: ong>Genuinely low in acidity, both perceived and measured, but very low in flavor as well.

Name: Espresso Blend
Review: ong>All of the Hevla samples in our 2012 low-acid cupping displayed green coffee taints, though the acidity, as advertised, was low, based both on a sensory reading of the cup and the pH of the finished beverage.

Name: 100% Colombia
Review: ong>Not recommended. Acidity avoiders are better off buying a good conventional dark roast, which should display similarly low acidity along with a bit more flavor.

Name: Guatemala Dark Roast
Review: ong>Those acidity-avoiders who can put up with a smoky, dullish, though reasonably nuanced and full-bodied cup with very low, measurably low, acidity.

Name: French Roast
Review: ong>An ultra-dark roast that preserves some pleasing chocolate character amid the smoky embers. Low in acidity, both perceived and measured.

Name: Espresso Roast
Review: ong>Robust, dark-chocolaty cup for acidity-avoiders.

Name: Sumatra Blue Batak
Review: ong>A pungently authoritative but cleanly refined Sumatra in a tactfully darker-roasted style.

Name: Brazil Cafe Zinho Esperanza Honey
Review: ong>Crisp rather than bright. An excellent choice for those who enjoy a quietly complex medium-roasted coffee with natural sweetness and low acidity.
Coffee Origin: Cerrado growing region, Minas Gerais State, Brazil.

Name: Colombia Granja La Esperanza Geisha
Review: ong>An exceptional, explosively floral version of the rare and celebrated Geisha profile.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto Pacamara
Review: ong>The combination of sweetness and austere beauty characteristic of the finest Kenyas displays in this exceptional coffee.

Name: Rusty’s Hawaiian Red Caturra Natural
Review: ong>A dried-in-the-fruit coffee for purists: sweetly opulent yet cleanly bright.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, southwestern corner of the "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Colombia Primavera COE First Place Winner
Review: ong>A classic coffee in every respect: big, sweet acidity, syrupy mouthfeel, lush yet lucid aromatics.
Coffee Origin: San Agustín growing region, Huila Department, southern Colombia

Name: Peaberry Medium Roast
Review: ong>Refreshing and exceptional in its delicate complexity, an orchard-like purity that could contrast with a rich dessert or brighten a light lunch. Don’t think about putting anything into it except your lips.
Coffee Origin: Holualoa, North Kona growing district, Hawaii.

Name: DTS8 Espresso Classic
Review: ong>A good choice for those who avoid brightness in espresso and value a slightly roasty, chocolaty pungency and syrupy mouthfeel. Excellent in short milk; should be able to handle taller, latte-sized milk as well.

Name: Haiti
Review: ong>A fine Haitian coffee of the traditional round, sweet-toned style with its chocolaty tendencies developed by a darker roast style.

Name: Guatemala El Diamante
Review: ong>Fine choice for those who prefer depth, resonance and natural sweetness in a brewed coffee.
Coffee Origin: San Pedro Necta, Huehuetenango growing region, Guatemala.

Name: Kenya Karinga
Review: ong>Those who like their dry, briskly bright cup nuanced with fruit and natural sweetness.

Name: Honey Pot Espresso
Review: ong>Those who prefer a rather tart but sweet, syrupy, complex straight shot that blooms beautifully without losing character in short milk.

Name: Ethiopia Tchembe
Review: ong>This intriguing variation on the dry-processed Ethiopia cup brings flowers and a fat, low-acid tropical fruit character forward, making it a good choice for those coffee lovers who pursue the exotic and different.

Name: Tierras Altas Premium
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a complex range of flavor in a briskly refreshing, classic breakfast cup.

Name: Dominican Republic Green Triangle
Review: ong>Balance without boredom in a lively, lighter-roasted cup.

Name: Kenya Rianjue AA
Review: ong>Delicate yet rich acidity in a gentle, floral-toned version of the great Kenya profile.

Name: Peru La Prosperidad Special Reserve Fair Trade
Review: ong>Enjoy this quiet, melodious coffee as you contemplate the complex and inspiring relationship it represents between you, the green buyers and roasters who live in the mountains of Vermont, and the farmer producers who live far in the remote mountains of northern Peru.

Name: Our Blend Fair Trade Certified
Review: ong>Those looking for a dependable, balanced morning cup. Classic and understated.

Name: Mocha Java
Review: ong>Those drawn to the simultaneously elegant and exotic. Pleasing when taken with whitener, but at its dramatic best black.

Name: Ka’u Coffee Natural Dried Red Caturra
Review: ong>Those who want to sample a quieter, cleaner version of the typically lushly fruity but often fermenty dried-in-the-fruit, “natural”-processed cup.
Coffee Origin: Ka'u growing district, southwestern corner of the "Big Island" of Hawaii.

Name: Honduras Finca El Gringacho Yellow Catuai
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a crisp cup with impressive tart-to-sweet balance and lemony-cocoa aromatics.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto Maragogype
Review: ong>A sensitively light-roasted, pleasing version of the rare, giant-beaned Maragogipe.

Name: Nicaragua Yellow Catuai Viennese Roast
Review: ong>Lovers of a roundly rich, deep-toned, slightly roasty cup.

Name: Honduras Las Penitas II
Review: ong>Those who enjoy crisp, fruit-toned white wines. Displays a hint of the elegantly dry, pungent fruit sensation associated with the Bourbon variety from which Pacas mutated.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Biloya
Review: ong>Delicate yet intense, this is an unusual, perhaps extreme, version of the already distinctive lemon and floral wet-processed Yirgacheffe profile.

Name: Panama Finca La Valentiina Geisha
Review: ong>Paradoxical excitement – honeyish sweetness supporting dry, tart fruit – in a lightish-roasted version of the celebrated Geisha variety.
Coffee Origin: Horqueta, Volcan growing region, western Panama.

Name: Ethiopia Gedeo Microlot
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the sweet fruit, brandy and pungent aromatic wood character typical of the best dried-in-the-fruit coffees. Rather light-roasted, but sensitively so.

Name: Ethiopia Gedeo Natural Process
Review: ong>Overall complexity and balance could make this selection an interesting starter dried-in-the-fruit coffee for purists who are tempted to stray from their clean and classic wet-processed habits.

Name: El Salvado Finca Ayatepeque Natural-Processed Pacamara
Review: ong>An impressively clean, fresh-toned version of the big, complex fruit character associated with dried-in-the-fruit coffees. The subtly distinctive and complex Pacamara varietal character doubtless also contributes to this coffee’s distinction.

Name: Nicaragua Bourbon City Roast
Review: ong>Exemplary example of the balanced, round, quietly deep-toned cup for which Nicaragua is particularly admired. Perhaps the finely balanced acidity and complex aromatics can be attributed to the heirloom Bourbon cultivar.

Name: Guatemala Hanupu
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a pure, soft yet intense, meadowy breakfast cup.

Name: Panama Geisha Aroma Roast
Review: ong>A lavish and memorable version of this celebrated and still rare coffee variety.

Name: Guatemala Pandora Pacamara Medium-Light Roast
Review: ong>Unusual and distinctive profile, with the savory/sweet complexity found in the best of any given year’s Pacamara. Should please both coffee adventurers and purists. Very sensitively roasted.

Name: Starlight Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the sweet and avoid the bitter in coffee and life. A coffee almost shocking in its natural sweetness. This is not the empty sweetness of refined sugar but rather of ripe fruit, floral honey and fresh-cut, aromatic wood.

Name: Garden Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a crisply lush, aromatically complex straight-shot espresso.

Name: Medium Roast Yellow Bourbon Pulped Natural
Review: ong>Pungent, grapefruit-like fruit and earth-toned aromatic wood make this Brazil rather Sumatra-like, though gentler and more delicate.
Coffee Origin: Mogiana growing region, Sao Paulo State, south-central Brazil.

Name: Colombia Tolimas
Review: ong>A Colombia of the true, good old school: Pure and brightly acidy yet accessibly syrupy and sweet-toned.

Name: Kenya Nyeri AB Gichatha-ini Signature Series
Review: ong>An almost transcendent expression of one of the world’s finest coffee types.

Name: Kenya AA Nyeri Ndiaini Espresso
Review: ong>Those who appreciate bright, somewhat dry, white table wines. Also an interesting change of pace for those who take their espresso with frothed milk; carries its distinctive profile with some authority even into tallish milk.

Name: Ethiopia Harrar
Review: ong>Those looking for excitement. Almost startling intensity and complexity in this unusually clean, bright Harrar.
Coffee Origin: Harrar region of eastern Ethiopia; east Java, Indonesia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Koke Coop FTO
Review: ong>A profile as complex and complete as a good blend yet still distinctively Ethiopian.

Name: Guatemala Quiche Chajulense FTO Espresso
Review: ong>A complex straight shot that translates well in short milk drinks.

Name: Special Roast
Review: ong>Only masochists. Our November 2011 supermarket sampling suggests better Robusta-heavy nationally branded canned blends are available at a comparable price.

Name: Premium Drip Coffee
Review: ong>For the curious, an object lesson in how bad a coffee can get if it fails to be developed in the roast. Could perhaps be seen as a botched exercise in anti-Starbuckism, a coffee as raw and woody as many Starbucks coffees are close to burned.

Name: Organic Premium
Review: ong>The organic seal is impressive even though the cup isn’t.

Name: 100% Colombian
Review: ong>A particularly bad dark-roasted Colombia at the tail end of a bad year for Colombias generally.

Name: House Blend
Review: ong>Least offensive of the canned Robusta-centered supermarket blends tested for our November 2011 cupping.

Name: French Roast
Review: ong>Except in the aroma, provides little of the pungent, charred intensity buyers of this ultimately dark-roasted coffee type love. Locally produced French roasts are likely to deliver considerably more.

Name: Africa Kitamu
Review: ong>Once past the aroma not much here. A whole-bean version of this blend bought from a Starbucks store doubtless would maintain more of the initially pleasing aromatics.

Name: Dark Roast Rainforest Alliance Certified
Review: ong>A smooth, quietly nuanced darker roasted coffee in a roast-and-ground canned format.

Name: Medium Roast Ground
Review: ong>Lovers of very delicate drip coffee.

Name: Dunkin’ Dark
Review: ong>A nicely balanced darker roasted cup at a value price.

Name: Original Blend
Review: ong>Those on a budget looking for a modest, balanced rendition of a classic American breakfast cup.

Name: Twisted
Review: ong>Those who appreciate a syrupy-sweet straight espresso and cappuccino-sized milk drinks.

Name: Guatemala Alotenango La Candelaria Espresso
Review: ong>Aficionados of single-origin espressos as straight shots and in short milk. Crisp and quietly complex.

Name: 100% Arabica 100% Italiano
Review: ong>A strong-charactered Northern Italian styled espresso that should work well in milk drinks of any size.

Name: Panama Elida Estate
Review: ong>An almost transcendently classic coffee in the depth and range of its sensation, intense yet balanced.

Name: El Salvador Nombre de Dios
Review: ong>Those who have learned to enjoy lighter-roasted coffees that bring the freshness of the coffee flower and fruit to the cup.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere
Review: ong>This dramatic expression of the citrus and floral Ethiopia cup should please those who enjoy spicy, complex dry white table wines.

Name: Colombia Finca San Luis Organic
Review: ong>Lovers of bright, delicate white table wines and coffee drinkers who enjoy the citrus and floral character of washed Ethiopia Yirgacheffe coffees.

Name: Guatemala El Injerto
Review: ong>Those who enjoy a bright but balanced, intensely fragrant breakfast cup.

Name: Reindeer Blend
Review: ong>Rusty and hearty but balanced and complex. The pungent, earthy fruit character of Indonesia coffees is particularly nicely framed by a moderately dark roast.

Name: Panama Elida Estate Natural Process
Review: ong>Fine example of a dried-in-the-fruit coffee, lushly yet freshly fruit-toned.

Name: Panama Elida: The Seasonal Tripel
Review: ong>A fine coffee for anyone or any occasion, but aficionados may particularly enjoy attempting to pick out the interwoven contributions of the three processing methods. The brandyish dried-in-the-fruit component is easiest to detect.

Name: Bali Kintamani Organic Rainforest Alliance
Review: ong>An aficionado’s dried-in-the-fruit coffee, brought to a light roast that foregrounds a just-picked, meadowy freshness and an unusual purity in the sweetly fermenty fruit notes.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Ardi
Review: ong>A dried-in-the-fruit coffee with rugged presence and big body that should please those who enjoy slightly edgy spirits: peaty single malts, the more rustic tequilas.
Coffee Origin: Guji Zone, Oromia Region, Sidama Province, Ethiopia.

Name: Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Kochere Micro-lot
Review: ong>Extravagant, high-toned and intense; should particularly please lovers of dry, spicy white table wines and perfumy gins.

Name: Espresso Havana
Review: ong>Surprisingly fruity for its darkish roast level; should hold up very well in latte-sized milk drinks.

Name: The Journey Espresso Blend
Review: ong>Those who enjoy resonantly deep, slightly carnal fruit in straight espresso. Roundly authoritative in short milk.
Coffee Origin: Ethiopia; Guatemala; Brazil; Burundi; Sumatra, Indonesia.

Name: Bluekoff Single Origin Thai Espresso Blend (A4+A5)
Review: ong>A versatile straight-shot espresso, with buttery body and bittersweet complexity, but perhaps at its best in short milk, where it maintains its individuality with richness and clarity.
Coffee Origin: Mae Suay, Chiang Rai, northern Thailand

Name: Costa Rica Tarrazu Montecielo
Review: ong>Richness and complexity in a darker roasted classic coffee.

Name: Costa Rica Export Reserve, Light Roast
Review: ong>Although a light roast in indicated on the packaging, by international standards this is a medium-dark roast, appealing to those who enjoy the slightly smoky, chocolaty character applied to a fine high-grown coffee by medium-dark roasting.

Name: Kenya Karinga
Review: ong>Well-balanced and distinctive with the complexity of the best Kenya coffees - 95 points, October 2011.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Guji
Review: ong>The aromatic fireworks of a fine dried-in-the-fruit Ethiopia with none of the fermenty downside. Splendid coffee.

Name: Sumatra Mandheling Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>The Sumatra earth and fruit character is a bit over the top here but most people who buy Sumatras are looking for energy over elegance anyhow.

Name: Organic Guatemla Finca Santa Isabel Natural Process
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the fruity, brandy-like (or port-wine-like perhaps) character typical of many dried-in-the-fruit coffees. Not a purist’s coffee - 89 points, October 2011.

Name: Organic Bali Kintamani Highlands
Review: ong>A dried-in-the-fruit coffee that walks on the wild side, with a fermenty, alcoholic sweetness that conveys considerable complexity as well as a faint overripe, composty shadow.

Name: Resiprocate FTO Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Medium Roast
Review: ong>A darkish, roast-influenced rendition of the classic Ethiopia Yirgacheffe fruit and flowers profile.

Name: Organic El Salvador Las Lajas
Review: ong>This naturally sweet coffee with its gentle acidity should please those who take their coffee black and find bright, acidy coffees too assertive and uncomfortable.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Gedeo Worka (Natural-Processed)
Review: ong>A style of coffee we used to call “after-dinner,” meaning it embodies an arm-chair-and-brandy sort of richness and authority.

Name: Ethiopia Sidamo Oromia FTO
Review: ong>Those coffee drinkers who avoid aggressive acidity and enjoy dark chocolate and nut nuance.
Coffee Origin: Sidama (also Sidamo) growing region, southern Ethiopia.

Name: Costa Rica Finca Santa Lucia Organic
Review: ong>Classic in its bright acidity; unusual in its rather deep, peach-and-melon fruit.

Name: Guatemala Quiche Chajulense Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Lovers of red table wines that pleasingly balance fruit and oak.

Name: Ethiopia Sidama Union Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Pure, crisply floral and citrus wet-processed Ethiopia of the classic style with Fair-Trade/organic credentials.

Name: Café Tierra Ethiopia Yirgacheffe Fair Trade Organic
Review: ong>Quietly distinctive Yirgacheffe should please lovers of classic coffees without alarming them with excessive aromatic fireworks.

Name: Organic Ethiopia Worka Coop Natural Process
Review: ong>Those who want difference and drama in their cup.

Name: Organic Costa Rica Las Lajas Natural Process
Review: ong>Naturally sweet but crisply nuanced, a coffee for lovers of soft, subtly complex white table wines.

Name: Estate of Kenya
Review: ong>One of the world’s most distinctive origins in a darker-roasted mode.

Name: Honduras El Cielito Single Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Subtle palates that appreciate a pleasing balance of sweeter chocolate-related notes and gently tart fruit in straight shot or short milk.

Name: Ethiopia Nigusie Lemma Natural Processed Single Origin Espresso
Review: ong>Lovers of sophisticated, high-cacao chocolates. Complex in the small cup, masterful in milk.
Coffee Origin: Limmu Kossa District, Jimma Zone, Oromia State, Ethiopia

Name: Guatemala Santa Isabel Natural Process SO Espresso
Review: ong>Brightly complex and elegant straight shot that maintains character in short milk and should sustain presence in taller milk beverages as well.

Name: Honduras Santa Barbara
Review: ong>Solidly satisfying breakfast cup with a quiet, tartly rich complexity associated with cultivars derived from the heirloom Bourbon variety of Arabica, in this case, Pacas.

Name: Ethiopia Natural Sidamo Korate Gr. 3 Organic
Review: ong>Those who enjoy the earthy coffees of Sumatra and Sulawesi should enjoy this distinctive variation on the style from Ethiopia.

Name: Kenya Gichathaini
Review: ong>Refreshing coffee; think the sweet, pink sort of grapefruit with deepening resonances of cedar and dark chocolate.

Name: Kenya Gichathaini
Review: ong>An acidity-lover’s coffee for sure, its grandly expressed brightness intensified by an unusually light roast.

Name: Kenya Thika Chania Estate Natural Process
Review: ong>Lovers of big, fruity red table wines and those coffee drinkers who already know they enjoy the lushly fruit- and brandy-toned character of a lightly fermented dried-in-the-fruit “natural” coffee.

Name: Kenya AA Kangocho
Review: ong>An almost creamily smooth mouthfeel and quiet, relatively restrained acidity makes this a particularly accessible rendition of the celebrated Kenya profile.

Name: Kenya AA Karogoto Microlot
Review: ong>Those who prefer the delicately refreshing possibilities of the Kenya profile.
